articles.headline: As Trump vs. Clinton Captivates World, Netanyahu Is Unusually Silent
articles.snippet: Four years after he was accused of meddling in the American election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is being careful not to take sides.
articles.abstract: Four years after he was accused of meddling in the American election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is being careful not to take sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For three hours, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel held forth on all sorts of topics — on Israel and the Middle East, on his record and on his plans. One subject that Mr. Netanyahu studiously avoided in his expansive conversation with American visitors last weekend, though, was the United States election.

articles.headline: EpiPen Price Rises Could Mean More Riches for Mylan Executives
articles.snippet: Filings show that under a one-time stock grant created in 2014, top executives stand to reap riches at least partly on the back of price increases on the EpiPen.
articles.abstract: Filings show that under a one-time stock grant created in 2014, top executives stand to reap riches at least partly on the back of price increases on the EpiPen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heather Bresch, chief executive at Mylan, the pharmaceutical giant that has been vilified for price increases on its EpiPen allergy treatment, maintains that her company has attained a sort of capitalist nirvana — it does good for others while doing well for itself.

articles.headline: Israel Courts Foreign Money in Effort to Become Gas Exporter
articles.snippet: The campaign is a major shift for a country whose government wrestled with how to regulate the energy industry.
articles.abstract: The campaign is a major shift for a country whose government wrestled with how to regulate the energy industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Israel’s energy minister laid on the charm as he spoke to a few dozen oil executives, contractors and analysts in a crowded hotel conference room about the country’s natural gas prospects.

articles.headline: Leaked Script Shows What Advisers Want Donald Trump to Say at Black Church
articles.snippet: A document obtained by The Times shows the wording suggested by advisers for Mr. Trump’s replies to questions about race, religion and racism.
articles.abstract: A document obtained by The Times shows the wording suggested by advisers for Mr. Trump’s replies to questions about race, religion and racism.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Donald J. Trump’s visit to a black church here on Saturday will be a major moment for a candidate with a history of offending the sensibilities of black Americans.

articles.headline: A Chinese Mystery: Who Owns a Firm on a Global Shopping Spree?
articles.snippet: Owners of Anbang, a Chinese insurer behind a wave of multibillion-dollar deals, include relatives and friends of its politically connected chairman.
articles.abstract: Owners of Anbang, a Chinese insurer behind a wave of multibillion-dollar deals, include relatives and friends of its politically connected chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pingyang County’s verdant hills still hint at a long-lost China. Rice paddies and villages surround its bustling towns, and in the fields, farmers wade into the mud to plant seedlings as they have for thousands of years.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: T.P.P. Faces Rough Road in Congress
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans are finding the politics of the far-reaching Trans-Pacific Partnership trade accord so risky that its prospects are uncertain.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans are finding the politics of the far-reaching Trans-Pacific Partnership trade accord so risky that its prospects are uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, reaching Asia on Friday, will reassure allies of his determination to win congressional approval of the far-reaching Trans-Pacific Partnership trade accord, but back home in congressional races, his party is on the air and online slamming it as a bad deal — and hitting Republicans for supporting it.

articles.headline: A Small Indiana County Sends More People to Prison Than San Francisco and Durham, N.C., Combined. Why?
articles.snippet: The new boom in American prisons is happening in mostly white, rural and politically conservative areas.
articles.abstract: The new boom in American prisons is happening in mostly white, rural and politically conservative areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEBURG, Ind. — Donnie Gaddis picked the wrong county to sell 15 oxycodone pills to an undercover officer.
articles.byline: By Josh Keller and Adam Pearce

articles.headline: A Lobbyist Wrote the Bill. Will the Tobacco Industry Win Its E-Cigarette Fight?
articles.snippet: Nearly two decades after the $200 billion settlement to compensate the public for health consequences of smoking, the industry still wields clout in Washington.
articles.abstract: Nearly two decades after the $200 billion settlement to compensate the public for health consequences of smoking, the industry still wields clout in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The e-cigarette and cigar industries have enlisted high-profile lobbyists and influential congressional allies in an attempt to stop the Food and Drug Administration from retroactively examining their products for public health risks or banning them from the market.

articles.headline: Slower Growth in Jobs Report May Give Fed Pause on Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The American economy added 151,000 jobs last month, a performance that could support the position of those within the Fed who favor delaying an interest-rate increase.
articles.abstract: The American economy added 151,000 jobs last month, a performance that could support the position of those within the Fed who favor delaying an interest-rate increase.

articles.headline: Samsung to Recall 2.5 Million Galaxy Note 7s Over Battery Fires
articles.snippet: The recall covers 10 countries and represents a blow to the South Korean company’s effort to catch up with the Apple iPhone.
articles.abstract: The recall covers 10 countries and represents a blow to the South Korean company’s effort to catch up with the Apple iPhone.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A ubiquitous source of power in most modern technology, lithium-ion batteries keep cellphones, laptops, electric cars and airplanes running. They are also the source of many problems, with some overheating, catching fire and even exploding.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Su-Hyun Lee

articles.headline: Surf’s Up, and the Ocean Is Nowhere in Sight
articles.snippet: A water park offering artificial waves in the Hill Country of Texas is part of a movement to bring surfing to the landlocked masses.
articles.abstract: A water park offering artificial waves in the Hill Country of Texas is part of a movement to bring surfing to the landlocked masses.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — What if everybody had an ocean, across the U.S.A.?
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Matt Higgins

articles.headline: ‘What if You Weren’t Afraid?’ and 4 More Money Questions From Readers
articles.snippet: Not surprisingly, parents and their values influenced how readers said they made decisions about saving, spending and giving.
articles.abstract: Not surprisingly, parents and their values influenced how readers said they made decisions about saving, spending and giving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Depression-era mothers. Blue-collar fathers. Disapproving elders. Parents who warn about regrets. Others whose financial limits were a statement of their values.
